overview: The measure, HB70 HD1 SD1, has now been passed by the Senate Committee on Judiciary and recommended for Third Reading without further amendments (HB70_SD1_SSCR1509_). The committee's report supports the bill's intent to enhance financial transparency for condominium owners by clarifying enforcement of budget summary and reserve requirements (HB70_SD1_SSCR1509_). The legislation continues to advance despite consistent opposition focused on the provision that shifts the burden of proving compliance to the association in legal disputes (HB70_SD1_TESTIMONY_JDC_03-25-25_).
economic_impact: The economic debate has sharpened around the potential for increased litigation costs, as opponents testified that shifting the burden of proof will expose associations to "costly frivolous litigation" (HB70_SD1_TESTIMONY_JDC_03-25-25_). Testimony further suggests this could cause insurance carriers to raise premiums or deny coverage, placing additional financial strain on unit owners (HB70_SD1_TESTIMONY_JDC_03-25-25_).
policy_impact: The bill's key policy, shifting the burden of proof to the association, was affirmed by the Senate Committee on Judiciary's decision to pass the measure without amendment (HB70_SD1_SSCR1509_). Testimony before the committee solidified this as the central point of contention, with opponents arguing it is "inconsistent with general principles of law" for a plaintiff to not bear the initial burden of proof (HB70_SD1_TESTIMONY_JDC_03-25-25_).
